linkTarget.anchoringText: Central to the Williston Basin, the formation is Late Devonian to Early Missis-sippian age and made up of five oil-bearing zones. The geologically unique top two oily layers, the Middle Bakken and the first bench of the Three Forks (commonly referred to as Three Forks 1), account for most of the Williston basin’s production. The Three Forks Formation is overlain by the Bakken throughout the central portion of the Williston Basin. Along the margins of the basin, where the Bakken is absent, the Three Forks is overlain by the Lodgepole Formation (Figure 1).

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Distribution of the Three Forks and overlying Bakken Formations (S.H. Nordeng and L.D. Helms NDGS & DMR, 2010)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Distribution of the Three Forks and overlying Bakken Formations (S.H. Nordeng and L.D. Helms NDGS & DMR, 2010)

linkTarget.anchoringText: The Three Forks Formation is overlain by the Bakken throughout the central portion of the Williston Basin. Along the margins of the basin, where the Bakken is absent, the Three Forks is overlain by the Lodgepole Formation (Figure 1). The Three Forks 1 has an average of 30.5 ft pay zone thickness, 65% oil saturation, and 6.9% porosity (Panjaitan et al, 2011). The wells referenced in this study are located in the Three Forks 1 layer, which is an interbedded dolomite and mudstone (Figure 2).

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Stratigraphic column of the petroleum source rocks in the Williston Basin

formatted-caption.caption-text: Stratigraphic column of the petroleum source rocks in the Williston Basin

linkTarget.anchoringText: The operator has several core acreage areas across the Williston Basin, as can be seen in Figure 3. This study focuses on Myrmidon and Hector areas. The geology across these areas varies drastically as there are changes in formation thickness (Figure 4), oil saturation, and geological structure. Study Wells 1 and 2 are both located in Dunn County (Hector area) where Study Wells 3 and 4 are located in Mountrail County (Myrmidon area).

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Operator’s acreage in Williston Basin

formatted-caption.caption-text: Operator’s acreage in Williston Basin

linkTarget.anchoringText: The operator has several core acreage areas across the Williston Basin, as can be seen in Figure 3. This study focuses on Myrmidon and Hector areas. The geology across these areas varies drastically as there are changes in formation thickness (Figure 4), oil saturation, and geological structure. Study Wells 1 and 2 are both located in Dunn County (Hector area) where Study Wells 3 and 4 are located in Mountrail County (Myrmidon area).

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Map of Three Forks thickness in study wells

formatted-caption.caption-text: Map of Three Forks thickness in study wells

linkTarget.anchoringText: Four wells in the study were completed in December 2014 – August 2015. Two of them (Study Wells 1 and 2) are located in Dunn County, ND, Bailey field (Hector Area); the other two (Study Wells 3 and 4) are located in Mountrail County, ND, Reunion Bay field (Myrmidon Area in Figure 5).

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Location of Myrmidon and Hector study areas

formatted-caption.caption-text: Location of Myrmidon and Hector study areas

linkTarget.anchoringText: All four laterals were landed in the first bench of the Three Forks formation with a true vertical depth (TVD) of approximately 10,750 feet and measured depth (MD) of 21,000 feet, providing roughly 10,250 feet of horizontal lateral. Study Well 1 was drilled in south direction with Azimuth of 183°. Study Wells 2, 3, and 4 were drilled in the north direction with Azimuth of 0-5°. An example of the completion for Study Well 1 is shown in Figure 6, and detailed comparison of the wells construction is provided in Table 1.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Study Well 1 construction diagram

formatted-caption.caption-text: Study Well 1 construction diagram

linkTarget.anchoringText: The size distribution and amount of components of the degradable composite fluid were optimized to create a low permeability plug with a minimum amount of material. Large particles are designed to pass through the perforations but be intercepted at the fracture entrance, while the smaller particles reduce the permeability of the formed plug (Figure 7). All the particles and fibers are made of degradable materials and require no additional treatment to be removed; thus, after the treatment, the solid materials degrade completely, opening the zone for production (Kraemer et al., 2014).

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Sequenced Fracturing Technique principle

formatted-caption.caption-text: Sequenced Fracturing Technique principle

linkTarget.anchoringText: The degradation of the composite pill is triggered by the temperature, and it is important that this process takes place at the correct time and in a controlled way. Material needs to hold its properties during fracturing treatment and then dissolve once reservoir begins heating back up. The bottom-hole static temperature for study wells varied between 230 to 235°F. Figure 8 shows largest particle degradation at 230°F.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Degradation plot of the largest particle size in water at 230F

formatted-caption.caption-text: Degradation plot of the largest particle size in water at 230F

linkTarget.anchoringText: In new well completions, diversion is a fundamental concept to access additional reserves through increased wellbore coverage. Multiple methodologies had been used to achieve diversion in a wellbore through the years that may be sorted in two categories, based on their target: restrict fluid to flow in the axial direction of the wellbore, and restrict fluid to flow in the perpendicular direction of the wellbore (Figures 9a and 9b).

image-wrap.label: Figure 9a
image-wrap.caption: Restrict fluid flow in the axial direction of the wellbore (Example: plugs, sliding sleeves and seats system)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Restrict fluid flow in the axial direction of the wellbore (Example: plugs, sliding sleeves and seats system)

linkTarget.anchoringText: In new well completions, diversion is a fundamental concept to access additional reserves through increased wellbore coverage. Multiple methodologies had been used to achieve diversion in a wellbore through the years that may be sorted in two categories, based on their target: restrict fluid to flow in the axial direction of the wellbore, and restrict fluid to flow in the perpendicular direction of the wellbore (Figures 9a and 9b).

image-wrap.label: Figure 9b
image-wrap.caption: Restrict fluid flow in the perpendicular direction of the wellbore (Example: Seq Fracturing technique Material, chemical diverters, ball sealers, others)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Restrict fluid flow in the perpendicular direction of the wellbore (Example: Seq Fracturing technique Material, chemical diverters, ball sealers, others)

linkTarget.anchoringText: The results observed on the treatment pressure plot made certain the occurrence of bridging and fluid flow restriction once the composite pill reached the perforations (Figure 10). One of the main observations, the injection rate was reduced to less than 5 bpm in order to maintain surface treatment pressure below 9,000 psi (pre-determined max pressure for equipment and completion capability).

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: Treating pressure increase in first composite pill field trial on new cemented P&P completion in Williston basin

formatted-caption.caption-text: Treating pressure increase in first composite pill field trial on new cemented P&P completion in Williston basin

linkTarget.anchoringText: The observations were made and recorded for each interval on which this technique was imple-mented, with the success criteria set at +500 psi. The pill was placed at a constant pump rate of 8 bbl/min on Study Well 1 and at 10 bbl/min on the remaining three test wells in order to easily observe the increase in pressure caused by the composite material plugging the fracture(s) taking fluid. Desired results (pressure differentials > 500 psi) were observed on 95% of the intervals on which the sequenced fracturing technique was employed. The success rate, as well as the statistical analysis of these obser-vations, is illustrated in Figures 11 & 12, respectively.

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: Diversion pressure success rate

formatted-caption.caption-text: Diversion pressure success rate

linkTarget.anchoringText: The observations were made and recorded for each interval on which this technique was imple-mented, with the success criteria set at +500 psi. The pill was placed at a constant pump rate of 8 bbl/min on Study Well 1 and at 10 bbl/min on the remaining three test wells in order to easily observe the increase in pressure caused by the composite material plugging the fracture(s) taking fluid. Desired results (pressure differentials > 500 psi) were observed on 95% of the intervals on which the sequenced fracturing technique was employed. The success rate, as well as the statistical analysis of these obser-vations, is illustrated in Figures 11 & 12, respectively.

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Diversion pressure distribution

formatted-caption.caption-text: Diversion pressure distribution

linkTarget.anchoringText: This is due to the preferred fracture submitting first (at a lower pressure), following the ball seat. Once the diverter was pumped and the initially propagated fracture was plugged, the pressure increase of the second breakdown (during pill placement) was observed to be, on average, 50% higher than that of the seating of the ball in the frac plug. Results from this comparison on Study Well 1 are illustrated below in Figure 13.

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: Comparative “Diversion”

formatted-caption.caption-text: Comparative “Diversion”

linkTarget.anchoringText: This indicates that significant differences in instantaneous shut-in pressures from before to after the pill’s placement are the result of changes in closure pressure (Pcl) between the two fracture entry points (pre-pill and post-pill), which further supports the hypothesis that new fractures are being treated following the placement of the pill. The success criteria for ΔISIP were met for 83 intervals out of the total 102 intervals on which the diversion technique was implemented, an 81% success rate. This is illustrated below in Figure 14.

image-wrap.label: Figure 14
image-wrap.caption: ΔISIP summary

formatted-caption.caption-text: ΔISIP summary

linkTarget.anchoringText: In the evaluation of the diverter’s performance, the surface treating pressure curves during each stage were also compared. It can be seen in Figure 15 that the treating pressure during the fracturing stage after the pill (Stage 2) is significantly higher than that of the pre-pill pressure (Stage 1). The cause of this increase in pressure during the second fracturing stage (following the pill) could be twofold.

image-wrap.label: Figure 15
image-wrap.caption: Treating pressure overlay

formatted-caption.caption-text: Treating pressure overlay

linkTarget.anchoringText: In the comparison of perforations open between Stage 1 and Stage 2 on Study Well 4, it was observed that open perforations were reduced by, on average, 23.2%. The following three scenarios may potentially explain the reduction in perforation counts observed here. Take, for example, one interval’s step-down test analysis that yielded results indicating nine perforations were open before the pill, and in the step-down test following the pill’s placement, only five perforations were open. See Figure 16a & 16b for illustration of these results.

image-wrap.label: Figure 16a
image-wrap.caption: Rate Step-down Test for Pre-Pill Stage

formatted-caption.caption-text: Rate Step-down Test for Pre-Pill Stage

linkTarget.anchoringText: In the comparison of perforations open between Stage 1 and Stage 2 on Study Well 4, it was observed that open perforations were reduced by, on average, 23.2%. The following three scenarios may potentially explain the reduction in perforation counts observed here. Take, for example, one interval’s step-down test analysis that yielded results indicating nine perforations were open before the pill, and in the step-down test following the pill’s placement, only five perforations were open. See Figure 16a & 16b for illustration of these results.

image-wrap.label: Figure 16b
image-wrap.caption: Rate Step-down Test for Post-Pill Stage

formatted-caption.caption-text: Rate Step-down Test for Post-Pill Stage

linkTarget.anchoringText: In this study, since the ISIPs were quickly collected and pumps were immediately brought back on-line at the same rate as before the temporary shutdown, it can be assumed that the net pressure from before to after the pill’s placement is maintained (keeping the fracture open), and it is therefore unchanged from Point 0 to Point 3 in Figure 17.

image-wrap.label: Figure 17
image-wrap.caption: Step-Down Test illustration

formatted-caption.caption-text: Step-Down Test illustration

linkTarget.anchoringText: A comparison was then made between the pressure relief achieved between the 1st acid spear (following the ball seat) and that of the 2nd spear (following the pill’s placement), and the results from this comparison are illustrated below in Figure 18. Data for the pressure relief following the ball seat – the pressure reduction from the 1st acid spear – was collected only for Study Well 3, as is shown in Figure 18 below, but this data set was used as benchmark for comparison of the 2nd acid spear relief for both Study Well 3 and 4.

image-wrap.label: Figure 18
image-wrap.caption: Acid relief comparison

formatted-caption.caption-text: Acid relief comparison

linkTarget.anchoringText: The results from this experiment indicated that very little pressure relief was achieved by the spear pumped following stage 1 (prior to the pill), but the acid spear following the pill generated a larger pressure reduction by, on average, a factor of 4.5 (with an average pressure reduction of 340 psi) than the former. These results confirmed that the pill was in fact plugging the fractures that were accepting fluid during Stage 1 of the sequenced fracturing treatment, due to the distinct difference in acid relief exhibiting the “newness” of the perfora-tions following the pill’s placement. These tests and their results are illustrated in Figure 19 and Table 5 below.

image-wrap.label: Figure 19
image-wrap.caption: Experimental acid test: Interval A

formatted-caption.caption-text: Experimental acid test: Interval A

linkTarget.anchoringText: The results comparing the ball seat to the pill placement for Study Wells 2, 3, and 4 are illustrated in Figures 37a-c in the Appendix. While Study Well 2 exhibited an average pill diversion pressure 10% lower than the ball seating differential, Study Wells 3 and 4 had diversion pressures 65% and 75% higher than their respective average ball seating differential pressures. See Fig. 37a-c for detail.
